content.title: IVUS in Venous Disease

definition.primary: Intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) used in the venous system to directly visualize and measure vein lumen, wall, and surrounding structures, providing superior detection of iliac vein stenosis compared to contrast venography alone.
key_concepts: Gold standard for iliac vein assessment
Detects stenosis often missed on venography (up to 50% of lesions)
Essential for accurate stent sizing and deployment

technology.principle: High-frequency ultrasound transducer at catheter tip provides 360-degree cross-sectional imaging of vessel wall and lumen

imaging_parameters.penetration: Variable, generally 4-8 mm into surrounding tissue
imaging_parameters.pullback: Motorized pullback for complete vessel assessment

venography_limitations: Single plane imaging misses eccentric compression
Dependent on contrast timing and injection technique
ivus_advantages: Cross-sectional imaging captures all compression planes
Direct lumen measurement independent of flow
stenosis_detection.diagnostic_yield: IVUS detects significant lesions in 50% of patients with normal or near-normal venography

diagnosis.findings: Left common iliac vein compression by right common iliac artery, often > 50% area reduction
Stenosis without prior DVT history, webs, spurs, external compression
Trabeculations, chronic wall thickening, residual stenosis, flow channels
Stenosis at IVC confluence, often bilateral involvement

procedural_guidance.rationale: Direct measurement of reference vessel diameter and lesion length
Ensure coverage of lesion, identify landing zones
Confirm full expansion, apposition, no residual stenosis
Edge dissection, stent malapposition, residual stenosis

stenosis_quantification.method: Compare minimum lumen area to reference segment area
stenosis_quantification.absolute_threshold: Minimum lumen area < 100 mm² in iliac vein suggests significant stenosis

approaches.advantages: Standard approach, allows complete iliac assessment
Alternative if CFV not accessible, allows femoral vein assessment
For IVC assessment, may be combined with femoral access

procedure: Advance IVUS catheter to target area (usually above confluence)
Measure minimum lumen area and reference diameters
integration_with_intervention: Pre-stent: Identify lesion, measure vessel diameter for stent selection
Post-stent: Confirm expansion, rule out edge dissection

technical: Image quality affected by blood pool, requires flush
Cannot assess beyond vessel wall (limited penetration)

outcomes_evidence.impact_on_management: IVUS changes treatment plan in 25-50% of cases compared to venography alone

content.statement: IVUS in Venous Disease is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Deep-Venous that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding IVUS in Venous Disease helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of IVUS in Venous Disease include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of IVUS in Venous Disease.

learning_objectives: Understand the principles of IVUS technology
Recognize the advantages of IVUS over venography for iliac vein assessment
Apply IVUS measurements for stenosis quantification
Integrate IVUS into venous stenting procedures
Identify common IVUS findings in venous disease
key_points: IVUS is the gold standard for iliac vein assessment
Venography misses up to 50% of significant lesions detected by IVUS
IVUS is essential for accurate stent sizing and deployment
> 50% area reduction is generally considered significant stenosis
IVUS should be used in all iliac vein stenting procedures
clinical_pearls: Don't rely on venography alone - always use IVUS for iliac vein assessment
External compression may require treating an apparently 'normal' segment
Post-stent IVUS confirms adequate expansion and apposition
IVUS findings often drive decision to treat in patients with symptoms and 'normal' venography
